message.content:
We need to “build” an inventory value as follows. (In many systems “inventory” is tracked only for goods that are purchased then later “sold ”. In our set‐of–transactions none of the “Initial…” entries are inventory goods so we start at 0. Then all “Purchase” lines add inventory at cost while every “Sale” of these products “uses” up inventory at the “cost_amount” recorded on the sale.)

Step‑by‑step:

1. Sum up all the “Purchase” transactions that add to the stock:
 • Purchase20231231001: 1,100,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231002: 240,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231003: 90,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231004: 300,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231005: 320,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231006: 850,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231007: 480,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231008: 2,300,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231009: 1,400,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231010: 1,700,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231011: 300,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231012: 60,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231013: 340,000.00  

Total purchases = 1,100,000 + 240,000 + 90,000 + 300,000 + 320,000 + 850,000 + 480,000 + 2,300,000 + 1,400,000 + 1,700,000 + 300,000 + 60,000 + 340,000  
  = 9,480,000.00

2. Sum up all “Sale” transactions that remove inventory – we use the “cost_amount” listed on each sale to indicate the inventory cost used.
Going through each “Sale…“ row we get (with cost_amount values):
 • Sale20240102003: 50,000.00  
 • Sale20240102004: 150,000.00  
 • Sale20240103006: 80,000.00  
 • Sale20240103007: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240104008: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240105009: 200,000.00  
 • Sale20240105010: 20,000.00  
 • Sale20240106012: 60,000.00  
 • Sale20240106013: 150,000.00  
 • Sale20240107015: 150,000.00  
 • Sale20240107016: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240108018: 250,000.00  
 • Sale20240108019: 20,000.00  
 • Sale20240109020: 20,000.00  
 • Sale20240109021: 50,000.00  
 • Sale20240110023: 150,000.00  
 • Sale20240111024: 200,000.00  
 • Sale20240112025: 20,000.00  
 • Sale20240113027: 30,000.00  
 • Sale20240114028: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240114029: 80,000.00  
 • Sale20240115031: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240115032: 500,000.00  
 • Sale20240116034: 60,000.00  
 • Sale20240117035: 80,000.00  
 • Sale20240117036: 400,000.00  
 • Sale20240118038: 50,000.00  
 • Sale20240118039: 250,000.00  
 • Sale20240119041: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240120042: 20,000.00  
 • Sale20240120043: 50,000.00  
 • Sale20240121044: 10,000.00  
 • Sale20240122045: 500,000.00  
 • Sale20240123047: 80,000.00  
 • Sale20240123048: 250,000.00  
 • Sale20240125052: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240126054: 400,000.00  
 • Sale20240127055: 150,000.00  
 • Sale20240128057: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240129058: 20,000.00  

Now, if you add all these “cost_amount” figures the total equals 5,000,000.00.

3. Therefore the ending inventory cost (the “Inventory End Value”) is
  Total Purchase cost – Total cost sold = 9,480,000.00 – 5,000,000.00 = 4,480,000.00

Finally, since no opening inventory was set up, the “Inventory Initial Value” is 0.00.

So we report:

{
  "Inventory Initial Value": "0.00",
  "Inventory End Value": "4480000.00"
}

Below is the answer in the required JSON format. 

Final Answer:

{"solution": {"Inventory Initial Value": "0.00", "Inventory End Value": "4480000.00"}}
